Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.search

Class Search<A extends Action>

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.search.Search<A>
Type Parameters:
A - the type of action used in the plans this search produces
All Implemented Interfaces:
Worker.Getter<Result<A>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
ProgressionSearch
public abstract class Search<A extends Action> extends Object implements Worker.Getter<Result<A>>
A search represents the process of finding one or more plans that are solutions to a planning problem. A search is one specific configuration of one approach for solving one problem. Searches are created by planners.

Though the problem and settings cannot be changed, it is possible to change the initial state from which this search will start and the goal value that a plan must achieve. Any solution returned by this search must be a plan which can be executed from the current initial state and which will increase the author's utility up to or above the the current goal.

A search should maintain its state after returning a solution because it may be asked to resume and find additional solutions. A search can be reset (meaning it can discard its internal state and reset counters for things like the number of nodes visited) when the setStart(State) method is called.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Field Details

    • problem

      public final Problem problem
      The problem this search is finding solutions for

    • searchLimit

      public final long searchLimit
      The maximum number of nodes which may be visited while finding one solution. This setting does not limit the total number of nodes visited, only the number of new nodes that can be visited during a single search. The constant Planner.UNLIMITED_NODES represents no limit.

    • spaceLimit

      public final long spaceLimit
      The maximum number of nodes which may be generated while finding one solution. This setting does not limit the total number of nodes generated, only the number of new nodes that can be generated during a single search. The constant Planner.UNLIMITED_NODES represents no limit.

    • timeLimit

      public final long timeLimit
      The maximum number of milliseconds that may elapse while finding one solution. The constant Planner.UNLIMITED_TIME represents no limit.

    • authorTemporalLimit

      public final int authorTemporalLimit
      The maximum number of actions a solution plan produced by this search may use to improve the author's utility. This can be thought of as the limit on the length of the main plan. The constant Planner.UNLIMITED_DEPTH represents no limit.

    • characterTemporalLimit

      public final int characterTemporalLimit
      The maximum number of actions a solution plan produced by this search may use to justify why an character would take an action (the limit includes the action itself). This can be thought of as the limit on the length of a character's plan when characters imagine how an action can improve their utility. The constantPlanner.UNLIMITED_DEPTH represents no limit.

    • epistemicLimit

      public final int epistemicLimit
      The maximum depth that each character's theory of mind (what one character believes another character believes, etc.) can be searched. Theory of mind is always infinite, and this setting does not change how it behaves; it only limits which states will be visited by the search. A value of 0 means the search will never visit states that represent what a character believes the state to be. This does not mean character beliefs are not modeled (they are). It also does not necessarily mean the search will fail to find solutions that contain character actions (in some cases, it still can). As long as the states needed to explain character actions are generated, actions will be explained regardless of whether they are visited by the search. However, a value of 0 would prevent the solution from finding actions that can only be explained by plans that will not actually work. These kinds of mistaken explanations can only be found if the search visits the states that represent the hypothetical plan. A value of 1 means the search will visit states that represent what a character believes. A value of 2 means the search will visit states that represents what one character believes another believes, and so on. The constant Planner.UNLIMITED_DEPTH represents no limit.

  • Constructor Details

    • Search

      public Search(Problem problem, long searchLimit, long spaceLimit, long timeLimit, int authorTemporalLimit, int characterTemporalLimit, int epistemicLimit)
      Constructs a new search with a given problem and settings.
      Parameters:
      problem - the planning problem this search will find solutions for
      searchLimit - the maximum number of nodes that may be visited while finding one solution
      spaceLimit - the maximum number of nodes that may be generated while finding one solution
      timeLimit - the maximum number of milliseconds that may elapse while finding one solution
      authorTemporalLimit - the maximum number of actions in the author's plan
      characterTemporalLimit - the maximum number of actions in the plans characters use to justify their actions
      epistemicLimit - the maximum depth in a character's theory of mind to search

  • Method Details

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object

    • get

      public Result<A> get(Worker.Status status)
      Finds the next solution to this search's problem. A solution is a plan which can be executed from this search's initial state and which increases the author's utility up to or above this search's goal value.

      This method may take a long time to run, so the provided status object should be periodically updated with the method's progress.

      If this method has already been called, and setStart(State) has not been called to reset this search in the interim, this search should maintain its internal state after this method returns because this method may be called again to return additional solutions.

      This search should maintain its internal state even after setGoal(Number) is called; however, if the goal is set to a lower value, the search does not need to revisit plans which previously would not have been considered solutions but now would be due to the lowered goal.

      This method only needs to find plans which increase the author's utility to or above what it is in the initial state. If the goal for this search is less than or equal to the author's utility in the initial state, only plans which increase the author's utility above the initial state are considered solutions (in other words, plans which do not increase the author's utility are not solutions, even if the author's utility would meet or exceed the goal after the plan is executed).

      Practically speaking, this method is simply a call to a constructor for the result object, which in turn calls run(Progress, Status). This is to ensure the result this method returns has already been allocated in case an OutOfMemoryError occurs while searching for a solution. Thus, this method generally should not be overridden; instead, searches should implement the abstract method run(Progress, Status).

      Specified by:
      get in interface Worker.Getter<A extends Action>
      Parameters:
      status - a status to update while the search runs
      Returns:
      a result object detailing the work done while finding (or failing to find) a solution to the problem

    • getStart

      public abstract State getStart()
      Returns the initial state of the world from which a solution plan must be executable. Unless changed by the setStart(State) method, the initial state should be the one defined by the planning problem.
      Returns:
      the initial state of the world before planning begins

    • setStart

      public abstract void setStart(State state)
      Sets the initial state of the world from which a solution plan must be executable. This method resets this search object, meaning it should discard its internal state, should start over (from the newly set initial state) the next time get(Status) is called, and may reset counters such as the number of nodes visited.
      Parameters:
      state - the new initial state of the world before planning begins

    • getGoal

      public abstract Number getGoal()
      Returns the author utility value that a solution plan must reach or exceed to be considered a solution by this search.
      Returns:
      the author utility value which must be reached or exceeded for a plan to be considered a solution

    • setGoal

      public abstract void setGoal(Number goal)
      Sets the author utility value that a solution plan must reach or exceed to be considered a solution by this search. This method does not reset this search; its internal state should be maintained.
      Parameters:
      goal - the new author utility value which must be reached or exceeded for a plan to be considered a solution

    • getVisited

      public abstract long getVisited()
      Returns the total number of nodes visited during all calls to get(Status) since the last time this search was reset using the setStart(State) method.
      Returns:
      the total number of nodes visited since this search was reset

    • getGenerated

      public abstract long getGenerated()
      Returns the total number of nodes generated during all calls to get(Status) since the last time this search was reset using the setStart(State) method.
      Returns:
      the total number of nodes generated since this search was reset
